narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: fundamental math knowledge about linear algebara
Linear Algebra
I gained a lot of knowledge about linear algebra, though a lot of it felt self-taught.
Matrix operations, describing and solving linear systems as matrices and vectors, nullspaces and vectorspaces, projections and least squares approximations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors
I learned about matrix operations.
I solidified my knowledge of various linear algebra concepts, including vector and matrix properties and manipulations, vector spaces, linear transformations, and eigendecompositions.
Basics of a variety of subjects and tools within linear algebra
linear algebra basics
Basic skills and tools in linear algebra
Basic linear algebra concepts (eg vector spaces, linear transformations, projection, etc) and how to apply them.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: not well taught. not organized. did not know where I stood in terms of my grade until the last week of the semester.

Strengths: I felt very prepared for the final exam Weaknesses: the class felt very disconnected, like the concepts we go over in p-sets was different than what we learned in discussion sections which was different from what we go over in the exams. I also felt like the communication in the class wasn't great, like we really didn't have the material to prepare ourselves for the final until the last minute. You can get things out of this class, but it will have to be mostly self-taught.

While the content is very interesting, it is extremely badly taught. Both professors made mistakes in recorded videos without ever acknowledging them and appear to have cared very little about the course. The TA, on the other hand, is wonderful, and having the choice of when to take midterms/exams was very much appreciated.

The strength of the course was its breadth.  I felt exposed  but not overexposed  to a number of relevant linear algebra concepts, and capable of carrying them forward into future work and applying these techniques to different classes of problems.  The pace and depth of the course were both good.  The homework assignments were largely enjoyable  most problems that were assigned were of appropriate rigor and corresponded to notes and examples from class.  There were always one or two problems, however, on each homework assignment that seemed completely unrelated to the techniques or examples shown in lecture, forcing me to email a ULA to get clarification.  

Weaknesses included those certain, frustrating homework problems as well as poor instruction from both the professor and TA.  The class was co-taught, with Ofir and Yariv alternating weeks of recording the lectures.  I felt that Yariv was marginally better at explaining concepts than Ofir, but they were both subpar.  Students would be well-served by going through the textbook alongside lecture in an effort to catch any omissions in instruction, cross-reference poorly explained concepts, and connect the various theorems and concepts to each other.  The professors did quite a poor job on this last point.  In the course of studying for the exams, I came to realize just how interconnected many of the class concepts were.  The instructors did not emphasize this or elucidate these very clear, concrete connections; I only understood their relations to one another as I went through the textbook
I wish the answers to homeworks and exams were posted after grading so that I could have improved as the semester went along instead of waiting until the final exam

Strenght: ULAs are helpful 
Weaknesses: Course is super messy, lectures are basically just three examples and then they give all types of weird problems on PSET/Tests, professors are super vague about grading and material
Weaknesses - extremely disorganized and lectured were incredibly hard to follow
The recorded lectures were succinct, and live sessions were a great opportunity to ask questions and flesh out understanding.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think we should have learned concepts in live virtual lectures. The recorded lecture/live recap didn't really work in my opinion. Also, I wish we had more insight about what to make of our midterm grades sooner!!

Professors blocked office hours at inconvenient times for students without our input. They should be more aware that we have other classes to attend.
Recorded lectures are nice because students can go back to them, despite the ones for this particular course being terrible. A lack of explanation, weird notation, poor handwriting, and no time to ask real questions.

The course featured two prerecorded lectures that we could watch on our own time, which was helpful for integrating the class into a schedule flexibly.  The ULAs were willing to answer questions via email, which was of great use in understanding how to approach many homework questions.  I only attended a single discussion section with the TA.  Failures in virtual learning included lectures that often exceeded the normal amount of time wed have been in class under normal circumstances.  Additionally, there was no Zoom link posted for the final exam review session.

The recorded lectures were done very well which was awesome but many of the live sessions repeated the same exact notes. It wouldve been more helpful if the live session had different examples. This started happening toward the end of the course which was helpful
Recorded lecture + Seminar was a good format
The recorded lectures were terrible and so was live section
Live sessions were extremely helpful, since recorded lectures were non interactive.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes,
No

I would avoid it if you can. If you HAVE to take it like I did, be prepared to teach yourself all the concepts you go over and REALLY make sure you understand all of those concepts. Our TF would "guess" what concepts would be on our exams which could lead to you not studying material that actually does show up on the exams.

It's a good introduction to linear algebra, which is an essential skill for most engineering and science disciplines. If you're not a fan of proof based math, take this over 225. Don't expect to learn things with direct applications to your field, however. Most of it is relatively abstract math but if you're taking it alongside classes for your major you'll be able to see strong applications.

Do not take this if Professors Lindenbaum or Aizenbud are teaching. They are not very accomodating and not very good lecturers. If you need it for your major, the TA's will be the key to passing this course so please go to section.

No.  I took this course because I was excited to learn more about linear algebra, a fascinating and useful field of study.  The material in this course is not too hard or mind-bending or anything of the sort.  I would recommend learning about linear algebra, just not through this course.  Students who take this course wont have too difficult a time working through the homework or studying for the exams, but by the end of the semester theyll become tired and frustrated at the poor level of instruction.

The professors and TA dont seem to care about students or their learning  I understand that things are virtual, but they seemed more unenthusiastic, distant and disconnected than they could have been.  Lectures were unimaginably dull, and the instructors didn't seem to hide their disdain at teaching us. Youd think that Yale would assign engaging, charismatic professors to teach fundamental courses such as this, but the instructors for MATH 222 (and many other lower- and mid-level MATH classes) serve as evidence to the contrary.  

Another irksome aspect of the course was the instructors aversion to posting clear, thorough solutions.  I did well on the all the homeworks and, fortunately, didnt need to consult the solutions very often.  But exam solutions were largely cursory, failing to explicitly show all the steps involved in arriving at the answer.  If those solutions had been turned in on an actual exam, I find it hard to believe the submitter would have earned an A, so incomplete was the work.  Furthermore, midterm solutions were posted a whole 48 hours before the final exam was due to begin.  So much for learning from our mistakes and using prior assessments as study tools.

Finally, please know that if you are looking for a course that demonstrates concrete examples of how these tools can be used in science, medicine, machine learning, or anything else, then this isnt the course for you.  This wasnt too much of an issue for me, but students should be warned that there isnt much to the With Applications part of Linear Algebra With Applications.

Only if you have to take linear algebra. This class is so poorly run though. To illustrate this, here's an example. The professors did not mention anything about final format until the day before the final. The professors did not communicate anything about grading until the day of the credit d fail deadline. The professors did not post any homework solutions and only posted practice final solutions on day of final.
No, only take it if you need to
Yes, if youre interested in linear algebra and plan to take related classes in the future.
Interesting and Applicable topics, however the instructors this semester did not really engage with students.
